answers.author: Corey Orlosky
answers.text:
As you alluded to, even normalizing the value by population, you’ve got number of services provided, climate/region factors that influence service delivery (more folks needed to plow streets in snowy areas), volume of use of seasonal/part-time employees, even form of government that will affect what that value means.  
The variables would never make it into each and every conversation to properly contextualize whatever response is given, so I would say it’s better to try and frame the question in another way.  For the reasons above this is an extremely difficult question to answer at the organization level, but at the department or single service delivery area, this could be possible.  You could then ask the question, “How many city employees per thousand population does it take to deliver a certain level of performance for police services?”
Performance measurement can be used to ascertain certain variable factors (population and level of service provided) to show, for example, that the police department has X number of employees.  Using those numbers, you can then begin to assess what kind of service your jurisdiction delivers (or, wishes to deliver), and figure out a value for total employees number based off of that.  Can’t really be done at the top, city-wide, level, but could definitely be done on a department by department basis.  It also helps steer the discussion towards the ability to deliver a particular level of service to residents.
ICMA’s Center for Performance Measurement offers a way to answer these types of questions.  Please feel free to contact me at corlosky@icma.org, or 202/962-3693 for further discussion.

author: Gary Edwards
text: Is there a generally acceptable number of city employees for a municipal population?   For example, how many city employess per each thousand of the city population.  I assume there are variables, such as the number of services provided, but is there such a thing as a base number from which to start?
